headline.main: Transcript of the State of the Union Message From President Clinton

docs.abstract: Text of Pres Clinton's State of Union Message; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Following is President Clinton's State of the Union Message, as transcribed by The New York Times:      Mr. Speaker, Mr. Vice President, members of the 105th Congress, distinguished guests, and my fellow Americans:

docs.lead_paragraph: It sounds like a recipe for trouble. Ban all forms of tobacco in a prison where 80 percent of the more than 1,200 inmates and half the guards smoke or chew tobacco. But a week after the total ban started at the State Prison in Deer Lodge, officials said last week, there had been no trouble.

headline.main: More Prisons Limit Tobacco But See Little Early Trouble

docs.abstract: Montana's ban on all forms of tobacco in prisons is part of national trend toward tobacco-free prisons; trend is spurred by rising prison health costs and inmate suits; ban has gone into effect at Deer Lodge, Mont, prison where 80 percent of inmates and half guards smoke or chew tobacco; warden reports no early trouble (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the day he was to have what he would later call his ''meeting with the devil,'' Randy Warren woke up early. It was the last day of April 1997, and Warren had spent a restless night in a hotel at the Toronto airport, two hours from his home, awaiting the morning arrival of two strangers, businessmen from New Jersey. The strangers were executives of the Celgene Corporation, a tiny pharmaceutical company that is seeking Government approval to market thalidomide, the world's most notorious agent of birth defects. Warren, the founder and chief executive officer of the Thalidomide Victims Association of Canada, had come to provide these men with living proof of their product's ruinous past.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study calls into question the view that premenstrual syndrome is an emotional disorder, suggesting instead that its cause is biological. The study suggests that the symptoms of PMS stem from an aberrant effect on the brain of changes in blood levels of the hormones estrogen and progesterone, which are released monthly in cyclical fashion throughout a woman's childbearing years.

headline.main: Study Challenges Idea of PMS as Emotional Disorder

docs.abstract: New study indicates premenstrual syndrome is biological, not emotional, disorder; suggests symptoms stem from aberrant effect on brain of cyclical changes in blood levels of hormones estrogen and progesterone; study, directed by Dr Peter J Schmidt of National Institute of Mental Health, is published in New England Journal of Medicine; could change how PMS is regarded and treated (M)
